title: A Randomised, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of the H3 Receptor Antagonist, GSK239512 in Subjects With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer's Disease.
description_brief: This study aims to evaluate the cognitive enhancing effects and tolerability of GSK239512 compared to placebo in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease
description_detailed: This is a 16-week, Phase II, multi-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel group design study in male and female subjects with mild to moderate Alzheimers disease (AD). Subjects will undergo 2-week placebo run-in period before randomisation. They will undergo weekly review of safety, tolerability and cognitive performance measures.
drug: GSK239512 (selective histamine H3 receptor antagonist; brain‑penetrant small molecule)
explanation_target: Reason: The trial title and description state the study evaluates the cognitive enhancing effects and tolerability of GSK239512 in mild–moderate Alzheimer's disease. GSK239512 is described in the literature as a potent, brain‑penetrant histamine H3 receptor antagonist developed for treatment of cognitive dysfunction (i.e., pro‑cognitive mechanism via modulation of histaminergic/cholinergic/monoaminergic neurotransmission). citeturn0search6turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — drug name: GSK239512; drug type/mechanism: selective H3 receptor antagonist (small molecule, brain‑penetrant); clinical objective: improve cognition (episodic memory/attention) in AD compared with placebo; dosing/titration used in trials up to ~80 μg/day. This compound was tested in randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled Phase II studies that reported modest episodic memory effects but no broad clinical benefit on ADAS‑Cog. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Reflect: Classification check — GSK239512 is a small‑molecule H3 receptor antagonist intended to enhance cognitive function (memory/attention) by modulating neurotransmission, not a biologic targeting core AD pathology (amyloid or tau) and not aimed at primary neuropsychiatric symptom relief. Therefore the correct category is "cognitive enhancer." Supporting trial reports and registry/summary pages are cited above. citeturn0search0turn0search6
